statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.description:
Randy Foye scored 21 points and Allan Ray
added 16 leading No. 4 Villanova to a 78-35 season-opening victory
over Stony Brook on Friday night.
article.headline: Foye, Ray lead Wildcats over mismatched Seawolves
article.linkText: No. 4 Villanova doubles up on Stony Brook in opener
article.story: VILLANOVA, Pa. (AP) -- Villanova's high-scoring offense was matched by an impressive defensive effort in the Wildcats' season opener. Randy Foye scored 21 points and Allan Ray added 16 as Villanova (No. 4 ESPN/USA Today; No. 5 AP) routed Stony Brook 78-35 Friday night. Mike Nardi added 13 points for Villanova, which posted a 46-22 rebounding advantage, and forced 18 Seawolves turnovers. "Our guys pride themselves on defense," Wildcats coach Jay Wright said. "They enjoy the challenge. We want them to be consistent on every possession and that's what they did tonight." Wright also gave credit to Villanova's raucous fans, who were highly animated both before and during the game. "The crowd really set the tone early," he said. "Even in the dressing room before the game, we could hear them chanting." Foye had 17 of his points in the second half, including three 3-point shots. "I just let the offense come to me," he said. "I didn't try to rush my shots and had good looks." Utilizing a suffocating man-to-man defense, the Wildcats jumped out to a 27-10 lead with 8:42 left in the first half. A 19-4 run at the start of the second half gave Villanova a 56-20 advantage, and the lead ballooned to 67-26 with 5:46 to play. Will Sheridan had 11 rebounds and Foye had six assists for the Wildcats while Jason Fraser, whose career has been hampered by a series of injuries, added six points and seven rebounds. "It couldn't have been any harder," Stony Brooks coach Steve Pikiell said of debut with the Seawolves. "We have two freshmen walk-on starters and not a lot of veterans, but they played hard." Marcus Cox, Bobby Santiago and Tre Cunningham each had seven points for Stony Brook, which made only 16 of 50 shots (32 percent) and one of 11 from the foul line. About Villanova, Pikiell said: "It's great when you have great guards and they play very well together. I think Villanova is as good as any team in the county."
